results.title: Binning street
results.creator_credit: Gillian Coote and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Changing Australia”.
Looks at the range of people, culture, attitudes, traditions and the history that dwells in Binning Street, Erskineville. The program investigates current family life in Australian society in the 1980’s and how it has changed.

results.title: Savage indictment (A)
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Adler, Caroline Sherwood, Channel Four Television and Titus Films
results.brief_description: A look at Australia in the 1960’s through a court case against James Savage, an Aborigine, who was on trial in the United States for murder. Gives an account of the government policy which removed half-caste Aboriginal children from their natural parents and placed them with white families. Includes interviews with some of those children who are now grown up. Savage was sentenced to death in January 1990, a sentence subsequently commuted to life.

results.title: Last chance for the lucky country
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The six programs use archival material, case studies of products and people and comparisons with other nations to show how Australia has fallen behind other nations through not utilizing its intellectual and enterpreneurial talent. The programs are: “Cringe dwellers” tells how some of our world firsts were stolen by more resourceful countries. “The Backward frontiers” looks at rural innovations. “Desperately seeking solutions” compares our research and development with Japan and U.S.A. “Ordinary people, extraordinary ideas” looks at the future of innovation. “Inventing the future” a view of the new breed of entrepreneurs. “Up the J curve” the story of our industrial decay, pointing to the light at the end of the tunnel. Accompanied by one teacher’s guide and student activities.

results.title: The Story of the Olympics
results.creator_credit: Derek Conrad and Conrad Television Associates
results.brief_description: This video will delight anyone with a love of sport or a general interest in the history of one of the world’s greatest sporting events. From as early as the first Olympic marathon which was won, appropriately enough by a Greek water-carrier, to as recent as the Seoul 1988, when the return of the Russians pushed the United States into third place and the drugs issue made headlines a Ben Johnson was stripped of his medal, you can relive the triumph and the heartache that have combined to make the Olympics the inspiration that they are today.

results.title: Egypt: the habit of civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television, Central Productions and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Legacy”.
The civilisation of ancient Egypt was conservative in nature, drawing its optimistic base from the annual flooding of the Nile which brought sustenance to the nation. The unchanging stability of the cosmos was symbolised by divine kingship, centralised power and the massive buildings which represented that power. The many surrendered power to the few - a condition which still exists for the majority of people today. Similarly almost everyone today, shares the ancient Egyptians’ concern for life after death. Yet the conquests of Alexander, and the synthesis of cultures which followed, culminating in the dominance of Islam have done little to change these basic beliefs.

results.title: The Light beyond light & life; Using the telescope: astrophotography
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Infinity series”.
The human eye, even aided by powerful modern-day telescopes can only see a small fraction of the universe. This program shows how modern radio astronomy and computer imaging techniques have enabled us to see previously invisible objects, as well as more familiar ones, through the light of radio waves, ultra-violet, infra-red and x-rays. This episode of “Using the telescope” shows how a 4” and 8” telescope in conjunction with an SLR camera, and accessories can be used to take spectacular photographs.

results.title: A Brief history of time
results.creator_credit: Errol Morris, David Hickman, Gordon Freedman and Anglia Television
results.brief_description: A biography of brilliant physicist Professor Stephen Hawking who has expanded and re-evaluated our knowledge of science despite having ALS - Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis since the age of 21. An inspirational film exploring the infinite possibilities of the human mind in extending the boundaries of knowledge in regard to why we and the universe exist. The bold use of graphics and striking imagery address theories surrounding an expanding universe, the creation, black holes and past, present and future.

results.title: Broome and the Pearl Coast
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey, AFFC and Sorena
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Broome, in the remote north-west of Australia is famous for its pearling industry. Travelling the breadth of the Pearl Coast, Ted Egan encounters a number of extraordinary people like Yoshinori Maeda who came to Australia as a young man to fish, but decided to stay. The vast panoramic coast and desert of the north-west is explored, including the beautiful splendour of Deepwater Point, 200kms from Broome.

results.title: Batsmen (S)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Gillman, David Puttnam and Visnews Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Benson and Hedges golden greats of cricket”.
A comprehensive history of the game of cricket tracing the games’ development from the early nineteenth century to the present. The first part examines the careers of the most reknowned of international cricket batsmen including W. G. Grace, George Headley, Leonard Hutton, Bradman, Kapi Dev, Clive Lloyd, Ian Botham and Viv Richards. The video uses archival and television footage from the largest cricket and/or media libraries in the world.
